Description: Cutting-edge, exclusive AI sales intelligence provider
Example from Transcript: Currently it's only the 1% who is using it
Do: Position as innovative leader, emphasize early-mover advantage
Don't: Appear commoditized or available to everyone

Description: Selective about partnerships, won't work with direct competitors
Example from Transcript: We will not work for your direct competitors... nine times out of ten we say no
Do: Emphasize partnership quality over quantity
Don't: Accept any client regardless of fit

Description: Partners must have unique value proposition
Example from Transcript: For you, you have something very unique. That's what I would love to work together with you
Do: Highlight client's unique strengths
Don't: Work with generic consultancies or undifferentiated businesses

Description: European-built platform, not American tech stack
Example from Transcript: We always envision building a European software company. And not use an American tech stack to do it
Do: Emphasize European roots and hosting
Don't: Position as another American SaaS tool

Example from Transcript: Last company I exited was 2 billion in five years time... five software companies over the past 15 years
Do: Share founder track record with specific numbers
Don't: Skip credibility establishment or be vague

Description: Bootstrapped by choice to maintain control
Example from Transcript: I really want to be self funded. To have our own direction and not have a board of directors behind you saying you need to do this
Do: Emphasize independence and customer-first decisions
Don't: Present lack of funding as weakness

Description: MBA thesis turned reality after 10 years
Example from Transcript: This was my final thesis. Back then everybody was saying that I was crazy... then we found Alex who actually made it work
Do: Share the journey from idea to reality

Example from Transcript: At the end of the day, it's all about how we as humans actually operate together with intelligence
Do: Educate prospects on the why behind features

Example from Transcript: We see an uplift from 300 to 500%
Do: State results confidently with specifics

Example from Transcript: So let me switch here so this becomes more... here we have an overview of about 90,000 companies
Do: Show live demos and real data
Don't: Rely only on slides or theory

Description: Frames product as inevitable market direction
Example from Transcript: This is going to happen in the next 12 to 24 months. Every organization who will survive this transition will use these kinds of toolings
Do: Position as essential for future success

Description: Complex concepts made simple for internal selling
Example from Transcript: We have customers. Find us more customers like our customers. How? Agents search the whole world
Do: Create simple soundbites prospects can repeat to their boss
Don't: Use complex jargon like 'agentic CDP' or 'fourth pillar'

Description: Position as wanting to learn from prospect too
Example from Transcript: I would really love to learn also from you... how your setup is, how you're automating things, how you're using agentic AI
Do: Express genuine curiosity about their approach

Description: Ask tough probing questions while affirming success
Example from Transcript: 3.5 calls per day? Why? What are they doing the other 7 hours?... You're doing amazing as a company. Sorry for the million questions - I just want to understand
Do: Challenge assumptions directly but acknowledge their success
Don't: Be confrontational, judgmental, or beat around the bush

Description: Proactively addresses GDPR and data concerns
Example from Transcript: Before I joined AI-KIP... I was a typical German always saying DSK file is not GDPR... we can install this locally
Do: Lead with security credentials, offer local hosting
Don't: Wait for security objections to arise

Example from Transcript: The salesperson itself can connect their own transcripts... they are always under the control of which data
Do: Clarify data ownership and control

Description: Tool helps employees, not monitors them
Example from Transcript: It will mirror it to the employee itself... it is always helping that person to get to the sale faster
Do: Frame as employee empowerment tool

Description: German cloud providers, GDPR compliance, local option
Example from Transcript: Everything is hosted here... Schwarz IT and StackIT... German tech stack. We can put it locally on a machine here in your headquarters if needed
Do: Name specific German/European providers, offer on-premise option
Don't: Rely on generic 'cloud compliant' claims or force cloud-only

Example from Transcript: I reached out to the person directly saying I'm so sorry... I want to offer you a voucher to go to dinner. And they were very happy
Do: Handle complaints personally and generously

Example from Transcript: Not wasting too much time on researching for companies, but only prioritize your valuable time to close warm leads
Do: Emphasize time saved on research

Example from Transcript: We have 33 million companies... all registered companies in Europe in our database
Do: Quantify signal volume and data coverage

Description: Identifies hidden concerns in buying cycles
Example from Transcript: The engineer asked these questions. I didn't notice it during the meeting
Do: Show how tool catches missed signals

Example from Transcript: It will be much easier for sales and they will get a higher commission
Do: Connect features to financial outcomes

Example from Transcript: The company name is correct but the rest is garbage... identify the company and the entity behind it
Do: Acknowledge CRM data pain point, show how AI-KIP fixes it

Description: Find more customers like existing customers
Example from Transcript: We take the domain or the unique identifier... and then we abstract the ideal customer profile from that
Do: Explain lookalike concept simply

Example from Transcript: It's more an optimization problem... demand side focus
Do: Frame as optimizing existing capacity

Example from Transcript: I found out data.com sells it to everybody in the US at the same time. So that data and uniqueness is completely gone
Do: Emphasize unique data gathering vs shared databases
Don't: Rely on same sources as competitors

Example from Transcript: How is your go to market? Direct or indirect? What is the revenue from direct versus indirect? Does it change for geographic location?
Do: Ask detailed questions about go-to-market, channels, geography

Example from Transcript: We do an onsite workshop... use cases and what you want to automate. Workshop costs 5,000 EUR
Do: Propose workshops to define ICP and use cases, state pricing upfront
Don't: Jump straight to implementation or hide costs

Example from Transcript: Is there anything we can already send you on the concerns... where it's hosted, IT security
Do: Offer to send security/hosting documentation
Don't: Wait for prospects to request materials

Example from Transcript: What would be very interesting, if you have a list of 50 companies... we can already generate a list and put that into a demo
Do: Offer to demo with their real customer data

Example from Transcript: Then we can visit you in person in Ulm, which is always better to see each other
Do: Suggest in-person meetings for deeper discussions

Example from Transcript: It would be interesting that he participates also... I will talk to my boss about it
Do: Encourage involving boss/decision-maker in follow-up

Example from Transcript: We do co development as well. We only do that with a very limited select group of customers
Do: Offer co-development for strategic accounts

Description: Range from full service to learning session
Example from Transcript: We can imagine from let's say hire you for almost everything to just learn something today and see where it fits together
Do: Acknowledge spectrum of engagement options

Description: Switches between German and English naturally
Example from Transcript: My German speech is not so great... (proceeds in English)
Do: Accommodate language preferences

Example from Transcript: Agentic AI comes up with several tasks... they want our reasoning behind it
Do: Make AI concepts understandable

Description: Frames as collaboration not vendor relationship
Example from Transcript: That's what I would love to work together with you
Do: Use 'we' and 'together' language

Example from Transcript: We have customers, find us more customers like our customers - how? Agents search the whole world
Do: Provide simple phrases prospect can use with their boss
Don't: Expect prospect to translate complex pitch internally

Example from Transcript: What happens if a competitor uses the tool? We will not work for your direct competitors
Do: Offer contractual exclusivity

Example from Transcript: This is set up not that this will forward to head of sales... it will mirror it to the employee itself
Do: Reframe surveillance fears as empowerment

Example from Transcript: Every organization who will survive this transition will use these kinds of toolings
Do: Frame as competitive necessity

Example from Transcript: We understand per customer what the potential value is... we can find the right audiences for you also for the long tail
Do: Show capability for small company targeting (craftsmen, 1-2 person shops)

Example from Transcript: Chamber of commerce, Dun & Bradstreet, Google Maps verified... everywhere there is a register we pull in that data
Do: Name specific data sources transparently

Description: Address why other AI projects fail
Example from Transcript: 95% of real world tasks given to AI are failing... because they used ChatGPT and other generic LLMs to do complex tasks
Do: Explain difference between generic AI and specialized agentic chains

Example from Transcript: You have a scale of creepy versus cool. This was more towards the creepy part
Do: Acknowledge when personalization goes too far, adjust approach

Example from Transcript: There's no rule. You have to call there... 1 out of 10, 9 out of 10 are not interested
Do: Validate that identifying decision makers is hard

Description: Knowledge Interaction Platform beyond just sales
Example from Transcript: This goes throughout the entire organization, to every different department
Do: Position as enterprise-wide platform
Don't: Limit to single department use case

Description: AI that requests human reasoning to improve
Example from Transcript: 23 different tasks they wanted to perform but they want our reasoning behind it
Do: Explain human-AI collaboration model

Example from Transcript: Vacancy online, annual reports, new locations, factory permits - these are all signals
Do: List specific signal types

Example from Transcript: 300 to 500% uplift... salesperson saw company was in market, reached out, signed contract same day
Do: Share specific success stories

Example from Transcript: Organizations are built on three pillars: people, process and resources. And next to that, now you have intelligence layer
Do: Introduce intelligence as fourth pillar alongside people/process/resources
Don't: Present AI as replacement for existing pillars

Description: Risk of unorchestrated AI in applications
Example from Transcript: I'm feeling a future of AI silos where all the single layers have their own intelligence data that is not orchestrated
Do: Warn about fragmented AI approach, position unified layer

Example from Transcript: There are three differences: ideal customer, buyer persona (right person at right time), and signals (when are you there at right time)
Do: Explain three distinct layers of targeting

Description: Water dispensers - full platform replacement, 60% uplift in meetings, same-day contract signing
Example from Transcript: They kicked out all standard software... no ERP anymore, no CRM anymore... 10 meetings per week now 16... one person signed the contract the same day
Do: Reference transformational case study with specific metrics
Don't: Only share vague or incremental improvements

Example from Transcript: 30 different people on purchasing department... helping with B2B side to have right inventory at right time
Do: Show diverse use cases (purchasing, not just sales)
Don't: Only discuss outbound sales use cases

Example from Transcript: We're working with Acer... top tier accounts direct, distributors as well, clear preference for partners
Do: Reference recognizable brands when relevant

Example from Transcript: Is it direct or indirect? Do you have partners? What is the revenue from direct versus indirect?
Do: Map their channel strategy thoroughly

Example from Transcript: Does it change for geographic location? In Italy you have two people... Poland is not a distribution market
Do: Understand regional nuances

Example from Transcript: What are your priorities for 2026? Our priority until 2030 is growth... countries where we are not very well known
Do: Align solution to stated growth priorities

Example from Transcript: What is the limiting factor right now? The limiting factor is really the people, the human resources
Do: Identify bottlenecks AI-KIP can solve

Example from Transcript: Your main target group are really the craftsmen... small companies, one or two people
Do: Understand customer size and complexity

Description: Calculate capacity gaps and daily patterns
Example from Transcript: You have 99% of your capabilities unutilized... 3.5 calls per day? What are they doing the other 7 hours?
Do: Reframe their data to reveal optimization opportunity, dig into actual activity

Description: Understand sales capacity vs customer base
Example from Transcript: 800 active clients... each salesperson has 25 potential clients, two to five buying clients. Margin at 25% average
Do: Map sales capacity against customer base, understand economics
Don't: Ignore sales team structure or unit economics

Example from Transcript: This is like a bow tie, a go to market approach... partner, end customer, indirect motion, direct motion
Do: Use bow-tie visual to explain GTM strategy

Example from Transcript: Awareness, education and selection stage and which channel we're touching here
Do: Map customer journey through stages

Example from Transcript: We visualize that for them... filter by industry, product market fit, lifecycle
Do: Demonstrate filtering and segmentation visually

Example from Transcript: People don't get the fourth pillar, it's too fake for them... need to focus on sales intelligence
Do: Lead with simple value prop (lookalikes, signals)
Don't: Start with platform architecture or 'agentic CDP'

Example from Transcript: A few parts were important to take up the strategic levers. This is something important for him
Do: Note and leverage prospect's stated priorities
Don't: Deliver generic pitch regardless of context

Description: Background research and mock-ups before demos
Example from Transcript: We need to now work in background so we can shift the story towards his faith... mock something up because it would be too extensive to already program it
Do: Customize demo to prospect's industry, mock up concepts for discussion
Don't: Use same demo for every prospect or build everything before validating

Example from Transcript: He's in the biggest brand. He hits the top, and then every night for this, other brands
Do: Identify expansion to other business units

Example from Transcript: This direct selling approach would work better in Benelux, but an indirect way is better in Germany. In Germany, DSGVO... there would be so many people writing a very bad email
Do: Adapt for German market (indirect, attention-first), lead with GDPR compliance
Don't: Apply Benelux direct-sales approach to Germany or downplay data protection

Example from Transcript: This direct selling approach would work better in Benelux
Do: Be more direct with Benelux prospects

Description: Agents gathering data globally via proxies
Example from Transcript: We have agents who are actually scraping all different systems... across the world we have proxies to get that information in
Do: Explain data collection capabilities when asked
Don't: Be evasive about data gathering methods

Description: Can replace standard software stack, requires LLM updates
Example from Transcript: They kicked out all standard software... no ERP, no CRM. Reasoning models need updating every three months
Do: Show full platform replacement potential, explain maintenance transparently
Don't: Only position as add-on or hide ongoing requirements
